meta.title: Forensic Medicine NEET PG Revision E&D - 07-01-2024 - 2024-01-07

questions.text: A neurosurgeon at a private hospital has a standing agreement with a referring primary care physician. For every patient referred to the neurosurgeon, the primary care physician receives a certain percentage of the surgical fee. This arrangement has come under scrutiny during a routine audit by the healthcare regulatory authority. What is this controversial practice called?

options.label: C
options.text: Filing an FIR against the patient for not paying the fee

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Dichotomy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Dichotomy is an unethical and often illegal practice in which healthcare professionals split fees in return for patient referrals. It is important to avoid conflicts of interest in medical practice to maintain professional integrity and prioritize patient care.

questions.text: The following documents are exceptions to oral evidence in court except:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Postmortem reports.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Postmortem reports typically require oral evidence to be fully admissible in court, as the expert who conducted the examination may need to clarify or explain the findings. Other expert reports, like dying declarations, fingerprint reports, and chemical examiner’s reports, are exceptions to the rule and can often be accepted without additional oral testimony

questions.text: During a lecture, a senior resident explains to medical students the hierarchy of evidence in legal proceedings. When it comes to the weightage of different types of evidence in an Indian court, which one is usually prioritized by the judiciary in making decisions?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Oral

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Oral evidence holds a significant place in Indian legal proceedings. Courts often rely on oral testimony, especially when it is direct and credible. This testimony can be scrutinized through cross-examination, which helps in determining the truth and making judicial decisions.

questions.text: Dr. Ray, a forensic specialist, is in a conundrum as he receives simultaneous summons from various courts for his expert testimony - all scheduled on the same day. With the summons spread across different levels of the judiciary and case types, he needs to determine which court holds the primary claim on his attendance. Considering the hierarchy and the nature of the cases, which court should Dr. Ray prioritize for his appearance?

options.label: A
options.text: Summon from the High Court in a civil case

options.label: B
options.text: Summon from the Session Court in a criminal case

options.label: C
options.text: Summon from the Session Court in a civil case

options.label: D
options.text: Summon from the Chief Judicial Magistrate in a civil case

questions.correct_answer: A. Summon from the High Court in a civil case
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Summon from the High Court in a civil case

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In situations where multiple courts summon a professional, the hierarchy of courts takes precedence. Higher courts, such as the High Court , have greater authority over lower courts like the Session Court or Chief Judicial Magistrate, regardless of whether the case is civil or criminal.
  • ➤ hierarchy of courts
  • ➤ High Court

questions.text: During a trial of a case in high court examination of a witness is being carried out by the opposing party lawyer. The lawyer is questioning the accused and is trying to prove that the evidence was biased, inaccurate, inconsistent. This procedure can be done by the lawyer during?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Cross examination

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cross-examination is a crucial part of the legal process, where the opposing lawyer questions a witness to challenge the testimony presented, aiming to uncover inconsistencies, biases, or inaccuracies in the evidence. It is distinct from direct examination, which is conducted by the lawyer who called the witness to support their case.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man who was detained in police custody is found dead in his cell under unclear circumstances. The legal system mandates an inquest to ascertain the cause of death and investigate any wrongdoing. According to section 176 of the Code of Criminal Procedure (CrPC), which official is tasked with the investigation of deaths occurring under such legal custody?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Judicial magistrate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Under Section 176 of the CrPC , the Judicial Magistrate is primarily responsible for investigating deaths that occur in police custody. This ensures that the inquiry is handled fairly and independently of law enforcement, fostering trust in the legal system and preventing misuse of power.
  • ➤ Section 176 of the CrPC
  • ➤ Judicial Magistrate

questions.text: Burden to prove defense lies with the doctor in case of:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Res ipsa loquitor

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Under the doctrine of res ipsa loquitur , the burden to prove the absence of negligence lies with the healthcare provider. This principle is especially important in medical negligence cases where the circumstances themselves strongly suggest malpractice.
  • ➤ res ipsa loquitur

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy attends the surgery without an adult accompanying him. He has a sore throat. Legally, a general practitioner must:

options.label: B
options.text: Refuse to see him unless a responsible adult is present

options.label: C
options.text: Write to the parent asking them to come to the surgery

questions.correct_answer: A. Examine and prescribe as appropriate
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Examine and prescribe as appropriate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A child 12 years or older can consent to a general physical examination and subsequent treatment, such as prescribing medications for a sore throat. For more significant medical interventions, the consent age is 18 years , but for routine matters, doctors can treat patients without requiring parental or guardian presence at ages 12 and above.
  • ➤ 12 years or older
  • ➤ general physical examination
  • ➤ 18 years

questions.text: A surgeon returns home from a party after many pegs of alcohol and was called to perform an emergency operation. During the operation, the assisting staff noticed the surgeon’s hand shaking and instruments falling. He eventually nicks an artery and the patient collapses. Under which of the following terms will this incident be tried?

options.label: B
options.text: Civil negligence not amounting to criminal negligence.

questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Criminal negligence

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Criminal negligence occurs when a professional, such as a surgeon, acts recklessly or irresponsibly, putting patient safety at risk, especially when their conduct shows a clear disregard for consequences, such as performing surgery while intoxicated. This is a serious offense and can result in both legal consequences and professional sanctions.
  • ➤ Criminal negligence

questions.text: A patient is brought into the emergency room after a severe car accident. The patient is unconscious and in critical condition, with multiple injuries. In this situation, the healthcare team may need to perform various surgical procedures, such as: Emergency surgery to stop internal bleeding. Orthopedic surgery to repair broken bones. Neurosurgery to relieve pressure on the brain. Plastic surgery to address facial injuries. Thoracic surgery to treat lung injuries. Given the urgency of the situation and the patient's inability to provide specific consent, the healthcare team may ask a family member for consent to perform any necessary surgeries to stabilize and treat the patient's injuries, without giving details on specific type of surgery. This is a type of?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Blanket consent

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Blanket consent is used in emergency situations when specific details about multiple necessary procedures cannot be provided, and permission is obtained from a family member or legal surrogate to proceed with essential surgeries. This allows the healthcare team to act in the patient’s best interest without waiting for detailed informed consent.
  • ➤ Blanket consent

questions.text: In a complex medical malpractice lawsuit, Amit, a 40-year-old patient, underwent a routine laparoscopic cholecystectomy at a reputable hospital. The surgery was performed by Dr. Sheela, a highly skilled surgeon. However, during the procedure, an unforeseen event occurred. Sarah sustained a deep laceration to her abdominal aorta, a major blood vessel, which required immediate vascular surgery to repair. Despite the seriousness of the injury, Amit's legal team encountered difficulties in identifying the precise cause of the aortic laceration or pinpointing a specific act of negligence. There were no clear breaches of established surgical protocols, and Dr. Sheela's credentials and experience were impeccable. In the context of this challenging case, which legal doctrine might Amit's legal team invoke to establish negligence?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) "Res Ipsa Loquitur"

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Res Ipsa Loquitur is a legal doctrine used in medical malpractice cases when an injury occurs that ordinarily wouldn't happen without negligence. It shifts the burden of proof to the defendant to demonstrate that there was no negligence, making it a critical tool in cases where the specific cause of injury cannot be pinpointed.
  • ➤ Res Ipsa Loquitur

questions.text: Number of teeth at 7 years:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 24

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ By 7 years of age , most children have 24 teeth , including the original 20 primary teeth and the 4 permanent molars that usually erupt by this time. This is an important stage in dental development as the transition from primary to permanent teeth begins.
  • ➤ 7 years of age
  • ➤ 24 teeth

questions.text: Which permanent teeth do not erupt in sockets of temporary teeth:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Molars

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Permanent molars are unique because they do not replace any primary teeth, unlike premolars, canines, and incisors, which all erupt in the sockets of primary teeth. Molars erupt behind the primary teeth in a new position.
  • ➤ molars

questions.text: Which of the following feature is not related to the mandible of male in comparison to females?
questions.correct_answer: A. Angle of ramus- More obtuse
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Angle of ramus- More obtuse

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The angle of the ramus is less obtuse in males compared to females, resulting in a more angular appearance of the male mandible. This contrasts with other features such as a larger condyle, prominent mental tubercles, and greater symphyseal height, all of which are more pronounced in males
  • ➤ angle of the ramus

questions.text: A forensic anthropologist is examining a set of skeletal remains discovered at an archaeological site. The mandible is relatively well preserved. The focus is on determining the sex of the individual based on the mandible. Which of the following features will be found in male mandible as compared to female mandible?

options.label: A
options.text: Square Chin, less obtuse angle of mandible, greater body height at symphysis, greater breadth of ascending ramus

options.label: B
options.text: Round Chin, less obtuse angle of mandible, greater body height at symphysis, greater breadth of ascending ramus

options.label: C
options.text: Square Chin, more obtuse angle of mandible, greater body height at symphysis, greater breadth of ascending ramus

options.label: D
options.text: Square Chin, less obtuse angle of mandible, smaller body height at symphysis, greater breadth of ascending ramus

questions.correct_answer: A. Square Chin, less obtuse angle of mandible, greater body height at symphysis, greater breadth of ascending ramus
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Square Chin, less obtuse angle of mandible, greater body height at symphysis, greater breadth of ascending ramus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Male mandibles typically feature a square chin , less obtuse mandibular angle , greater body height at the symphysis , and greater breadth of the ascending ramus . These traits contribute to a more robust and angular appearance compared to female mandibles, which generally show rounder and softer features.
  • ➤ square chin
  • ➤ less obtuse mandibular angle
  • ➤ greater body height at the symphysis
  • ➤ greater breadth of the ascending ramus

questions.text: A person is accused of committing Rape. He claims to be adolescent. He is brought to the government hospital for age estimation to determine if he should be sent to juvenile home or an adult jail. The X-ray image of the pelvis is shown below. What is the age?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 17-18 years

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Skeletal maturity as seen in X-rays, particularly in the pelvis, is an important marker for age estimation in forensic cases. Fusion of ossification centers in the femoral head and trochanters is indicative of the 17-18 year range, which is crucial in determining whether the individual can be treated as a juvenile or adult in legal matters.
  • ➤ Skeletal maturity
  • ➤ 17-18 year

questions.text: Suspended animation may be seen with:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Electrocution

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Suspended animation, a state of temporary cessation of vital functions, may be seen in cases of electrocution, where immediate medical intervention can potentially reverse the effects and revive the person.

questions.text: A postmortem examination of a dead body reveals contracted muscles but no primary relaxation. This can be called as:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Cadaveric spasm

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cadaveric spasm is the immediate stiffening of specific muscles at the moment of death, typically seen in cases of sudden or violent death, with no preceding relaxation phase.

questions.text: What type of smell is produced by the decomposed body from the given image?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Odorless

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Mummification is a process in which the body becomes desiccated, leading to a thin, brown appearance. Due to the lack of moisture, mummified bodies are odorless because the bacteria responsible for producing foul smells in putrefaction cannot thrive.
  • ➤ odorless

questions.text: A person in a village sees a dead body floating in a nearby pond. He informs the police and the dead body is brought for post mortem examination. What is the likely place where postmortem staining will be seen?

options.label: B
options.text: In hands and feet in a glove and stocking pattern

options.label: C
options.text: On the dorsal aspect of the body, except back of chest and buttocks

options.label: D
options.text: Over face, neck, front of upper part of chest, upper and lower limbs

questions.correct_answer: D. Over face, neck, front of upper part of chest, upper and lower limbs
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Over face, neck, front of upper part of chest, upper and lower limbs.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a floating body, postmortem staining occurs on the dependent areas, which in this case are the face, neck, front of the chest, and limbs, as these areas are submerged and face down in the water.

questions.text: A forensic investigator is examining a series of bruises on a victim's body. To determine whether these bruises are artificial or true bruises, which of the following characteristics would be most useful to assess?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Color changes over time

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ True bruises exhibit a characteristic color change over time as they heal, making this progression the most reliable indicator to distinguish them from artificial bruises, which do not show similar changes.
  • ➤ Notes:
  • ➤ Notes:
  • ➤ The timeline can vary depending on factors such as the severity of the injury, location on the body, and the individual's healing process. Larger or more severe bruises may take longer to heal. The sequence of color change (from red to blue to green to yellow) is typical in true bruises as the body metabolizes the blood trapped in the tissues.
  • ➤ The timeline can vary depending on factors such as the severity of the injury, location on the body, and the individual's healing process.
  • ➤ Larger or more severe bruises may take longer to heal.
  • ➤ The sequence of color change (from red to blue to green to yellow) is typical in true bruises as the body metabolizes the blood trapped in the tissues.
  • ➤ This table is a useful tool in forensic investigations to help estimate the age of a bruise and differentiate between fresh and older injuries.

questions.text: The image below is seen in?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Windshield glass injury

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Windshield glass injuries commonly occur in car accidents and present as multiple superficial lacerations, also known as "sparrow feet" marks. These injuries are most often seen in drivers and front-seat passengers due to their proximity to the windshield.

questions.text: The image below is:

options.label: A
options.text: Ring fracture of base of skull

options.label: B
options.text: Hinge fracture of base of skull

questions.correct_answer: B. Hinge fracture of base of skull
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Hinge fracture of base of skull

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A hinge fracture of the skull is a severe injury that splits the skull into anterior and posterior halves, typically caused by high-impact trauma, such as a motor vehicle accident. It is most commonly associated with motorcyclists due to the nature of such accidents.

questions.text: Identify the range of the firearm wound:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Close Shot Entry Wound

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A close-range gunshot wound is identified by the presence of blackening and tattooing around the entry point, caused by the deposition of soot and gunpowder particles. This indicates that the firearm was discharged at a short distance from the victim. Table summarizing the characteristics of different gunshot wound ranges

questions.text: The following is a victim of a firearm injury. What is the suspected distance of the shot?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Intermediate range

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Intermediate-range gunshot wounds are characterized by stippling or tattooing around the entry wound, caused by unburnt gunpowder particles striking the skin. This finding helps estimate the distance of the firearm from the victim at the time of discharge. Table summarizing the characteristics of different gunshot wound ranges:

questions.text: The image below indicates?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Typical hanging

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Typical hanging is identified by a V-shaped, oblique ligature mark caused by the knot's position at the nape of the neck, consistent with gravitational forces.

questions.text: Identify the gestational age of the fetus if the Crown Rump Length is 21 cm, length of lower limb is 10 cm, gestational age of the fetus will be:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 6 to 7 months

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For a Crown-Rump Length less than 25 cm, Haase's rule estimates the fetal age by taking the square root of the length in centimeters. In this case, a CRL of 21 cm corresponds to a gestational age of approximately 6 to 7 months.

questions.text: Police officers found a completely burnt dead body of a person in a forest. They suspect that someone might have killed him and later burnt the dead body to avoid identification. Doctor while conducting the postmortem, found a significant finding in the larynx as shown below. This is suggestive of.
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Antemortem Burns

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The presence of soot particles in the larynx or trachea during an autopsy indicates that the person was breathing at the time of the fire, confirming that the burns occurred antemortem (before death).

questions.text: Police officer brings a 15-year-old male child to doctor for medical examination. Mother of the child gives the history that his uncle has been threatening and sexual assaulting him for past 2 years, which she came to know now and complained the police. After doing the complete examination, doctor examines the anus, which shows features as in the picture below. This is suggestive of:
questions.correct_answer: B. Repeated anal sex with child
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Repeated anal sex with child.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Repeated anal sexual abuse can lead to physical changes in the anus, including dilation, elongation, loss of normal folds, and thickened skin. These changes can be a sign of child sexual abuse and should be evaluated by a medical professional.

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl, accompanied by her mother, is brought to a lady police sub-inspector, alleging a history of sexual violence that occurred two days ago. The next course of action for the registered medical practitioner would be:

options.label: D
options.text: Documentation of injuries and examination findings

questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Take a detailed history.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of alleged sexual violence, healthcare providers must prioritize taking a detailed history from the victim to understand the circumstances of the assault, identify potential suspects, and determine the appropriate course of action.

questions.text: Psychological autopsy is?

options.label: A
options.text: Autopsy of brain and spinal cord

options.label: B
options.text: To inquire about the psychiatric illnesses of the deceased

options.label: C
options.text: Assessment of the mental state of deceased person before death

questions.correct_answer: C. Assessment of the mental state of deceased person before death
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Assessment of the mental state of deceased person before death

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A psychological autopsy is used to reconstruct the mental state of a deceased person prior to death, especially when the death is suspected to be a suicide or involves other unclear circumstances. It is a tool for understanding the psychological and social factors leading up to death.

questions.text: A factory worker was brought to the emergency room after consuming wood spirt with complaints of headache, vomiting and blurred vision. What treatment will you give the patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Fomepizole

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The treatment of choice for methanol poisoning is Fomepizole , which inhibits the enzyme alcohol dehydrogenase, preventing the formation of toxic metabolites such as formaldehyde and formic acid. Early treatment is critical to prevent severe complications like blindness and metabolic acidosis.
  • ➤ Fomepizole

questions.text: A male patient presented to hospital with tachycardia, hypertension, palpitations and pupil dilatation. He Is found to be a substance abuser. Which of the following drug withdrawal can cause the following symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Opioid

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Opioid withdrawal can cause autonomic symptoms such as tachycardia, hypertension, palpitations, and pupil dilation (mydriasis). Recognizing these signs is important for identifying opioid withdrawal in clinical settings.
  • ➤ Opioid withdrawal

questions.text: Identify the plant which produces a toxin of abuse potential?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Erythroxylum coca

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The plant Erythroxylum coca produces cocaine, a substance with a high potential for abuse due to its stimulating and addictive properties.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child comes to casualty with history of unknown poisoning by some seed/drug. On examination patient has dilated pupils, dry mouth, delirium and decreased secretions with hallucination. What poisoning should the doctor suspect?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Dhatura

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Students should recognize the symptoms of anticholinergic poisoning , including dilated pupils, dry mouth, and delirium. Dhatura poisoning is a classic example of anticholinergic toxicity and should be suspected in such cases.
  • ➤ anticholinergic poisoning
  • ➤ Dhatura poisoning

questions.text: Identify the active principle of the plant shown below?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Hyoscine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Students should recognize Datura and understand that its active principles include atropine , hyoscyamine , and hyoscine , all of which have strong anticholinergic effects. These alkaloids are responsible for the toxic effects associated with Datura poisoning.
  • ➤ Datura
  • ➤ atropine
  • ➤ hyoscyamine
  • ➤ hyoscine

questions.text: A 7-year-old child from an environment presents with pallor, fatigue, and abdominal discomfort. Laboratory investigations reveal a hemoglobin level of 9.5 g/dL and a peripheral blood smear demonstrates a peculiar finding shown below. Which of the following differential diagnoses is most likely responsible for this finding in this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Viral infection affecting erythropoiesis, causing aberrant RNA synthesis

options.label: B
options.text: Lead poisoning leading to abnormal iron metabolism, leading to intracellular iron accumulation within red blood cells

options.label: C
options.text: Autoimmune hemolytic anemia, caused by the production of autoantibodies against red blood cell antigens

options.label: D
options.text: Lead poisoning affecting heme synthesis and resulting in aggregates of ribosomal material within red blood cells

questions.correct_answer: D. Lead poisoning affecting heme synthesis and resulting in aggregates of ribosomal material within red blood cells
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Lead poisoning affecting heme synthesis and resulting in aggregates of ribosomal material within red blood cells.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Students should recognize basophilic stippling as a key feature of lead poisoning , resulting from the disruption of heme synthesis and the accumulation of ribosomal material in red blood cells. This is important in diagnosing children exposed to lead, which can lead to significant anemia and other systemic effects
  • ➤ basophilic stippling
  • ➤ lead poisoning
  • ➤ ribosomal material

questions.text: Which of the following chelating agents is recommended for acute Lead poisoning with signs of encephalopathy?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Dimercaprol + Calcium EDTA

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Students should understand that in acute lead poisoning with encephalopathy , the combination of Dimercaprol (BAL) and Calcium EDTA is the most effective treatment. Dimercaprol removes lead from the brain, while Calcium EDTA clears it from the blood and other tissues.
  • ➤ acute lead poisoning with encephalopathy
  • ➤ Dimercaprol (BAL)
  • ➤ Calcium EDTA
  • ➤ Dimercaprol
  • ➤ Calcium EDTA

questions.text: A 15-year-old male presents to ED in a coma with CPR in progress. A friend found him in the schoolyard. His friend confesses that the patient has been depressed over the past several days. His initial labs reveal hypocalcemia and a severe metabolic acidosis. The urine shows calcium oxalate crystals. What was the toxic ingestion?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Ethylene Glycol

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ethylene glycol poisoning causes hypocalcemia, severe metabolic acidosis, and calcium oxalate crystals in the urine. It should be treated promptly with Fomepizole to prevent the formation of toxic metabolites, and the patient may require hemodialysis if renal failure develops.
  • ➤ Ethylene glycol poisoning

questions.text: An approximately twenty-something year old female presents to the emergency department after she collapsed outside a bar. Physical Examination: T: 97.5°F HR: 60 bpm RR: 5 breaths per minute BP: 75/57 mm Hg Pupils are miotic but equal. Pulmonary: Clear to auscultation. CV: Regular rate and rhythm. Abdomen: Normal Neurologic: GCS = 6 (E1V1M4). Best treatment?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Naloxone

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of suspected opioid overdose, characterized by respiratory depression, miotic pupils, and decreased consciousness, Naloxone is the first-line treatment. It is an opioid antagonist that works rapidly to reverse opioid effects, particularly life-threatening respiratory depression.
  • ➤ Naloxone

questions.text: In a village, the residents find a new groundwater source. After intake of water from this source many villagers presented with nausea, vomiting, dark bloody stools, conjunctivitis, and a burning sensation in the throat and stomach. Which poisoning do you suspect in this case?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Arsenic

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Acute arsenic poisoning can occur from contaminated groundwater and is characterized by nausea, vomiting, dark bloody stools, burning sensations in the throat and abdomen, and conjunctivitis. Recognizing these symptoms is essential in identifying arsenic as a potential source of poisoning in environmental or occupational exposures.

questions.text: Alopecia, madarosis & skin rash, painful peripheral neuropathy, and confusion with lethargy are seen in?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Thallium poisoning

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Thallium poisoning is characterized by alopecia, madarosis, painful peripheral neuropathy, and neurological symptoms such as confusion and lethargy. The presence of hair loss is a distinctive feature that points towards thallium toxicity in cases of suspected poisoning.
  • ➤ Thallium poisoning

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman is brought to the hospital by emergency medical services after being found unconscious in a park. She is unresponsive to verbal stimuli and is breathing very shallowly. Friends who were with her mention that she had been using drugs at a party earlier. Her breathing rate is 6 breaths per minute, and her pupils are constricted. Her skin is pale, and she feels cool to the touch. Which of the following substances is most likely responsible for her presentation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Opioid

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ An opioid overdose is characterized by severe respiratory depression , constricted pupils (miosis) , and unconsciousness . This is a medical emergency requiring immediate treatment with naloxone , an opioid antagonist that can rapidly reverse the effects of opioids.
  • ➤ severe respiratory depression
  • ➤ constricted pupils (miosis)
  • ➤ unconsciousness
  • ➤ naloxone

questions.text: A 28-year-old male is brought to the emergency department with agitation, dilated pupils, and tachycardia. He appears restless and paranoid, and he is sweating profusely. His blood pressure is elevated. What is the likely cause of these symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Acute Cocaine poisoning

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Acute cocaine poisoning is characterized by sympathomimetic symptoms such as agitation, dilated pupils, tachycardia, sweating, and paranoia. Cocaine acts as a stimulant, increasing catecholamine levels and leading to heightened physical and psychological symptoms.
  • ➤ Acute cocaine poisoning
  • ➤ sympathomimetic symptoms

questions.text: A welder presents to the emergency department with fever, chills, headache, fatigue, and muscle aches after working with galvanized steel for several hours. The place of work is poorly ventillated. On physical examination, his vital signs are stable, and there are no specific findings on examination. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient's symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Metal Fume Fever

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Metal fume fever is an acute, self-limiting condition caused by inhalation of metal fumes, particularly zinc oxide from galvanized steel. The symptoms mimic flu or malaria, including fever, chills, and muscle aches, and typically resolve within 24 to 48 hours.
  • ➤ Metal fume fever
  • ➤ zinc oxide

questions.text: Activated charcoal is ineffective in poisoning of:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Ethyl Alcohol

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Activated charcoal is ineffective in treating poisoning by alcohols , heavy metals , corrosives , and organophosphates . It cannot bind to these substances and thus is not recommended in cases of poisoning with these agents.
  • ➤ ineffective
  • ➤ alcohols
  • ➤ heavy metals
  • ➤ corrosives
  • ➤ organophosphates

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient arrives at the hospital emergency department presenting with gastrointestinal distress. The patient complains of severe abdominal pain, frequent vomiting, and watery diarrhea. During the physical examination, the medical team observes that the patient's stools emit an unusual faint glow. The patient appears disoriented and fatigued. The medical history reveals that the patient attended a local festival the previous day and consumed various food items there. The following exposures might be contributing to which substance toxication?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Phosphorus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ White phosphorus poisoning is characterized by luminescent stools and vomit, along with severe gastrointestinal distress. Phosphorus is a hepatotoxic poison, and ingestion can lead to serious systemic effects, particularly on the liver.
  • ➤ White phosphorus
  • ➤ luminescent stools

questions.text: Gastric lavage can be performed in case of poisoning by:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Carbolic acid

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Gastric lavage can be performed in cases of carbolic acid poisoning due to its unique effect on the stomach lining, which becomes hard and leathery, reducing the risk of perforation. Lavage is generally contraindicated in corrosives, convulsive agents (like strychnine), and volatile poisons (like kerosene) due to the risk of perforation, aspiration, or worsening of symptoms.
  • ➤ carbolic acid

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient presents with complaints of pain, numbness, and darkening of the lower extremities. Physical examination reveals gangrene in the feet and lower legs. The patient reports a history of residing in an area with known arsenic-contaminated drinking water. Which of the following conditions is most likely responsible for the patient's presentation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Blackfoot disease

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Blackfoot disease is a form of severe peripheral vascular disease associated with chronic arsenic exposure and is characterized by gangrene of the lower extremities. Arsenic poisoning can lead to ischemia and necrosis of tissue due to compromised blood flow, ultimately resulting in gangrene.
  • ➤ Blackfoot disease
  • ➤ chronic arsenic exposure
  • ➤ gangrene

questions.text: A hiker in a forested area is bitten by a snake while exploring. Hikers begin to experience symptoms such as swelling, pain, and bruising at the bite site. The hiker remains conscious but is anxious. What is the most appropriate initial first aid response for this snake bite?

options.label: A
options.text: Applying a tourniquet above the bite site to restrict blood flow and prevent venom spread.

options.label: B
options.text: Cutting open the wound and attempting to suck out the venom.

options.label: C
options.text: Immobilizing the affected limb at or slightly below heart level and transporting the person to a medical facility.

options.label: D
options.text: Applying ice packs directly to the bite area to reduce swelling and pain.

questions.correct_answer: C. Immobilizing the affected limb at or slightly below heart level and transporting the person to a medical facility.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Immobilizing the affected limb at or slightly below heart level and transporting the person to a medical facility.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The correct first aid for a snake bite is to immobilize the limb , keep it below heart level , and transport the patient to a medical facility for further treatment. Avoid using tourniquets, cutting the wound, or applying ice, as these methods can worsen the condition.
  • ➤ immobilize the limb
  • ➤ below heart level
